text: for years automakers were met with
disapproval for not making
fuel-efficient cars but at this year's
auto show in detroit there are plenty of
green cars on display trouble is
americans don't really want them these
are the kinds of cars that americans
want this is Toyota's four by four the
Tacoma with the economy getting better
and the price of gas becoming cheaper
these big cars are becoming more
affordable cars have come a long way in
fuel efficiency the 50s and 60s were a
time of gas guzzling muscle cars but
enter the oil crisis of the 1970s gas
prices soared so cars became lighter and
car makers learned valuable lessons
about the American consumer I think the
biggest lesson that came out in 1970s
was you have to have a diverse product
lineup you have to have the products
that are economical that fit into the
market and you can't just have large
cars that are heavy with big engines
ladies and gentlemen introducing the
Chevrolet Volts General Motors unveiled
a long-range all-electric concept car
and an updated version of its hybrid but
it's a tough time to get car buyers to
think of saving on gas how concerned you
about launching these two electric
vehicles and hybrid vehicles at a time
in which gas prices aren't really on the
forefront again is you look that's a
situation here but when you look around
the globe and you look at you know from
an environment perspective from a
regulatory perspective it's a natural
path that we're on we're going to
continue it hasn't changed our path one
moment but the path is changing for
consumers some of whom are taken by the
lower prices at the pumps for some
reason it does something to the American
psyche I think it's like you're starting
at that price once a week or twice a
week often you fill up and it really
does dictate what people buy even if it
doesn't really make sense in the long
term these low fuel prices may be
temporary but it's not dampening the
spirits of some consumers who are eager
to live large sameer Hussein BBC News
Detroit
